topics.title: What Is Ethics? Morality Beyond 'Just Follow the Rules'

hook.text: A child asks: 'Why is stealing wrong?' You answer: 'Because it's the rule.' They ask: 'But who made the rule?

buildup.text: Ethics is the philosophical study of right & wrong â€“ not just WHAT the rules are, but WHY they exist & whether they're.

discovery.text: Three main approaches: consequentialism, deontology, virtue ethics. Each answers 'why' differently.

twist.text: No single framework solves every dilemma. That's not a bug â€“ it's the nature of moral complexity.

climax.text: Ethics doesn't give you answers. It gives you better questions and more rigorous ways to think about them.

punchline.text: Rules tell you what to do. Ethics tells you why â€” and when to break them.

quiz.question: What are the three main approaches to ethics?

topics.title: Moral Intuition: That Gut Feeling of Right and Wrong

hook.text: You see someone kick a dog.

buildup.text: Moral intuitions: automatic, emotional responses to ethical situations that occur before conscious reasoning.

discovery.text: Jonathan Haidt's 'social intuitionist model': moral judgments are usually intuitions first, reasoning second.

twist.text: Haidt's dumbfounding experiments: people say incest is wrong but can't explain why. The intuition has no argument.

climax.text: Intuitions are fast & often right â€“ but they can be biased, culturally conditioned, & manipulated.

punchline.text: Your moral gut is usually right.

quiz.question: What did Haidt's research show about moral judgments?
options: They typically begin as emotional intuitions, with reasoning following after

topics.title: Is vs. Ought: The Fact-Value Gap

hook.text: 'Animals eat other animals, so it's natural for humans to eat meat.' From 'animals do it' to 'we should do it.' Is.

buildup.text: David Hume's guillotine: you can't derive an 'ought' from an 'is.' Facts about the world don't automatically generate.

discovery.text: The naturalistic fallacy: assuming that what IS natural IS good. But disease, violence, and parasitism are also natural.

twist.text: The reverse is also a fallacy: 'that's unnatural, so it's wrong.' Glasses, surgery, and penicillin are all unnatural.

climax.text: Facts inform ethics but don't determine it.

punchline.text: Nature tells you what IS. You still have to decide what SHOULD be.

quiz.question: What is Hume's 'is-ought' problem?
options: We should always follow natural law
Factual statements about what IS cannot alone prove what OUGHT to be
Moral facts are the same as scientific facts

topics.title: Moral Relativism vs. Moral Universalism: Is Anything Always Wrong?

hook.text: Some cultures practiced human sacrifice. Others practice capital punishment. Others ban both.

buildup.text: Moral relativism: right & wrong are determined by cultural context.

discovery.text: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights: an attempt at universal moral principles â€“ agreed by cultures with.

twist.text: Relativism's paradox: if all moralities are equally valid, then cultures that believe in universal morality are also.

climax.text: The practical middle: respect cultural difference, but don't abandon the principle that suffering is bad wherever it.

punchline.text: Cultures differ on what's wrong.

quiz.question: What is the paradox of extreme moral relativism?
options: If all moralities are equally valid, then anti-relativist moralities are also valid, creating a contradiction

topics.title: The Euthyphro Dilemma: Does God Decide What's Good?

hook.text: Plato asked: Is something good because God commands it? Or does God command it because it's good?

buildup.text: Horn 1: if good = whatever God says, then God could command torture and it would be good. Morality becomes arbitrary.

discovery.text: Horn 2: if God commands things because they're already good, then goodness exists independently of God.

twist.text: This 2,400-year-old dilemma still applies to any authority-based ethics: 'It's right because the law says so.' Same.

climax.text: The lesson: morality can't be grounded solely in authority.

punchline.text: If 'good' just means 'whatever the authority says,' then nothing is truly good.

quiz.question: What does the Euthyphro dilemma challenge?
options: The idea that morality can be grounded solely in divine or authoritative command

topics.title: Utilitarianism: The Greatest Good for the Greatest Number

hook.text: A city needs a hospital or a concert hall. The hospital saves lives. The concert hall brings joy to thousands.

buildup.text: Jeremy Bentham: the right action is the one that produces the greatest happiness for the greatest number.

discovery.text: Bentham's 'felicific calculus': measure pleasure vs.

twist.text: The dark side: utilitarianism can justify sacrificing one person to save five.

climax.text: Every policy decision â€“ healthcare allocation, tax policy, environmental law â€“ implicitly uses utilitarian reasoning.

punchline.text: Maximize happiness. Minimize suffering. Simple to say.

quiz.question: What is the core principle of utilitarianism?
options: The right action produces the greatest happiness for the greatest number

topics.title: Act vs. Rule Utilitarianism: Follow the Rule or Break It?

hook.text: Lying is usually bad. But lying to a murderer about where your friend is hiding? Act utilitarianism says: lie.

buildup.text: Act utilitarianism: evaluate EACH action individually.

discovery.text: Rule utilitarianism: 'If everyone followed this rule, would happiness increase?' 'Don't lie' generally works â€“ even if.

twist.text: Act utilitarianism is more flexible but prone to rationalization: 'THIS lie is justified.' Rule utilitarianism is.

climax.text: Most institutions use rule utilitarianism while individuals use act utilitarianism. Both have trade-offs.

punchline.text: Rules exist because individual calculations fail. But sometimes, rules fail too.

quiz.question: What is the key difference between act and rule utilitarianism?
options: Act utilitarianism evaluates each action individually; rule utilitarianism follows generally beneficial rules

topics.title: Peter Singer and Effective Altruism: Ethics by the Numbers

hook.text: A child is drowning in a pond. You'd ruin your $200 shoes to save them.

buildup.text: Peter Singer's argument: physical distance doesn't change moral obligation.

discovery.text: Effective altruism: use evidence & reason to determine the most effective ways to help others.

twist.text: Critics: it reduces ethics to calculation.

climax.text: Singer's challenge remains powerful: we routinely spend on luxuries while others die from preventable causes.

punchline.text: Distance isn't a moral category.

quiz.question: What is Peter Singer's core argument about distance and moral obligation?
options: We should only help people we can see
Physical distance doesn't reduce our moral obligation to prevent suffering
Charity should be limited to our community

topics.title: The Utility Monster: When Maximizing Goes Wrong

hook.text: Imagine a being that gets 1,000x more pleasure from every resource than you do. Utilitarianism says: give it everything.

buildup.text: Robert Nozick's 'utility monster': a thought experiment showing that pure utility maximization can lead to monstrous.

discovery.text: If one person's happiness counts more, utilitarianism demands we sacrifice everyone else's well-being. The math works.

twist.text: Real-world utility monsters exist: dictators who claim their vision justifies mass sacrifice.

climax.text: This is why rights matter: they set floors that utility can't breach.

punchline.text: Maximizing happiness sounds perfect.

quiz.question: What does Nozick's utility monster thought experiment demonstrate?
options: That pure utility maximization can justify sacrificing everyone's well-being for one being

topics.title: Consequentialism's Blind Spot: Can Good Intentions Produce Evil?

hook.text: A doctor secretly kills one healthy patient to harvest organs saving five others. Net utility: positive. Is it ethical?

buildup.text: Consequentialism judges actions solely by outcomes. But this ignores HOW the outcome was achieved â€” the means matter.

discovery.text: Bernard Williams: 'moral luck' â€“ consequentialism makes morality hostage to outcomes you can't control.

twist.text: A firefighter saves a child. The same child grows up to be a dictator. Was the rescue wrong?

climax.text: The lesson: outcomes matter, but they can't be the ONLY thing that matters. Process, rights, and character also count.

punchline.text: Good outcomes don't always mean good ethics. How you get there matters.

quiz.question: What is 'moral luck' in consequentialist ethics?
options: The morality of an action depends on unforeseeable outcomes, making ethics hostage to chance

topics.title: Kant's Categorical Imperative: Act As If It Were Universal Law

hook.text: 'What if everyone did that?' Your mother's question is actually Immanuel Kant's most famous philosophical principle.

buildup.text: Kant's categorical imperative: act only according to rules you could will to be universal laws for everyone.

discovery.text: Test: 'Can I lie?' If everyone lied, trust collapses & lying becomes pointless.

twist.text: The problem: Kant says lying is ALWAYS wrong â€“ even to a murderer asking where your friend is hiding.

climax.text: Kant's insight survives the edge cases: consistency matters.

punchline.text: If you wouldn't want everyone to do it, you shouldn't do it either.

quiz.question: What does Kant's categorical imperative require?
options: Act only according to rules you could will to be universal laws for everyone

topics.title: Treating People as Ends, Not Means

hook.text: You hire someone just to impress a client. You date someone just to make your ex jealous. You're using people as tools.

buildup.text: Kant's second formulation: 'Treat humanity, in yourself and others, always as an end and never merely as a means.'

discovery.text: People have inherent dignity â€“ they're not instruments for your goals.

twist.text: 'Merely' is key: it's okay to use a taxi driver's services if you also respect them as a person.

climax.text: Slavery, exploitation, & manipulation all violate this: they reduce persons to tools.

punchline.text: People are not tools. They're not stepping stones. They're not means.

quiz.question: What does Kant mean by treating people as 'ends in themselves'?
options: Respecting their inherent dignity and autonomy, never using them merely as instruments

topics.title: Rights-Based Ethics: Lines That Cannot Be Crossed

hook.text: Can the government torture one person to save a million? Utilitarianism says maybe. Rights-based ethics says: never.

buildup.text: Rights-based ethics: individuals have inviolable rights that no calculation of overall good can override.

discovery.text: John Locke: natural rights to life, liberty, & property exist before government.

twist.text: Rights conflict: your right to free speech vs. my right to not be harassed. Whose right wins?

climax.text: The power of rights: they protect the individual against the majority. Without rights, democracy becomes mob rule.

punchline.text: Rights are the things you keep even when the majority wants to take them.

quiz.question: What is the core idea of rights-based ethics?
options: Individuals have inviolable rights that cannot be overridden by calculations of overall good

topics.title: The Doctrine of Double Effect: Intent vs. Side Effect

hook.text: A doctor gives pain medication knowing it will shorten the patient's life. They intend to relieve pain, not to kill.

buildup.text: Doctrine of double effect: it may be permissible to cause harm as a side effect of achieving good, but not to cause.

discovery.text: Thomas Aquinas originated it.

twist.text: This is why most people accept bombing a military target but reject using a human shield.

climax.text: Critics: the distinction between 'intended' & 'foreseen' is too thin.

punchline.text: What you intend matters. What you foresee also matters.

quiz.question: What does the doctrine of double effect distinguish between?
options: Harm caused as an intended means versus harm caused as a foreseen side effect

topics.title: Moral Duty vs. Supererogation: What's Required vs. What's Heroic

hook.text: A soldier jumps on a grenade to save their squad. Heroic â€“ but was it morally required?

buildup.text: Supererogation: actions that are morally praiseworthy but go beyond what duty requires.

discovery.text: The distinction matters: if everything good is required, then failing to be maximally altruistic is always wrong.

twist.text: Consequentialism struggles here: if your goal is maximum good, then every dollar spent on yourself instead of saving.

climax.text: Deontology preserves supererogation: you have duties, but going beyond them is praiseworthy, not required.

punchline.text: Morality has a floor and a ceiling. Most of life happens in between.

quiz.question: What is supererogation?
options: Actions that are morally praiseworthy but go beyond what is required by duty

topics.title: Aristotle's Golden Mean: Virtue as Balance

hook.text: Too much courage is recklessness. Too little is cowardice. The right amount? Courage.

buildup.text: Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics: virtue (arete) is a character trait at the mean between excess and deficiency.

discovery.text: Generosity is between extravagance & stinginess. Honesty is between bluntness & deception.

twist.text: The mean isn't mathematical. It varies by person and situation. A soldier's courage looks different from a parent's.

climax.text: Virtue isn't a rule to follow â€“ it's a skill to develop through practice, mentorship, & reflection.

punchline.text: Virtue isn't what you do once. It's who you become through practice.

quiz.question: What is Aristotle's 'golden mean'?
options: Virtue as the balanced character trait between two extremes (excess and deficiency)

topics.title: Character vs. Rules: What Kind of Person Should I Be?

hook.text: Rules tell you: don't lie. Virtue ethics asks a deeper question: what kind of person do you want to be?

buildup.text: Virtue ethics shifts focus from 'What should I do?' to 'What kind of person should I be?' Character is primary.

discovery.text: An honest person tells the truth not because a rule says to, but because dishonesty is incompatible with who they are.

twist.text: The critique: virtue ethics is vague. 'Be virtuous' doesn't tell you what to do in a specific dilemma.

climax.text: The defense: no ethical system gives specific answers to every case.

punchline.text: Rules are for beginners. Character is for life.

quiz.question: What is the central question of virtue ethics?
options: What kind of person should I be?

topics.title: Moral Exemplars: Learning Ethics from Real People

hook.text: You don't learn courage from a textbook. You learn it from watching someone be brave.

buildup.text: Moral exemplars: people whose lives embody virtues so clearly that they become models for others.

discovery.text: Aristotle: 'We become what we repeatedly do.' But we first need to see what virtue looks like.

twist.text: Heroes are flawed. Gandhi was harsh to his family. Mandela had a violent past.

climax.text: The modern crisis: social media creates false exemplars. True moral exemplars are often quiet, unphotogenic, & unknown.

punchline.text: You don't need a perfect hero. You need a real one.

quiz.question: Why does virtue ethics emphasize moral exemplars?
options: Because virtue is learned through observing and emulating people who embody it
To create a list of rules

topics.title: Care Ethics: Relationships as the Foundation of Morality

hook.text: A mother doesn't save her child because of a 'universal moral law.' She does it because she loves them.

buildup.text: Care ethics: morality is rooted in relationships, empathy, & responsiveness to others' needs â€“ not abstract principles.

discovery.text: Gilligan argued traditional ethics was male-biased: focused on justice & rules while ignoring care, context, &.

twist.text: Critics: if morality is about caring for those close to you, what about distant strangers?

climax.text: The synthesis: care AND justice are both needed. Care without justice is favoritism.

punchline.text: Morality isn't just rules. It's also showing up for people. Both matter.

quiz.question: What does care ethics argue is the foundation of morality?
options: Relationships, empathy, and responsiveness to others' needs

topics.title: Moral Luck: Are You Responsible for What You Can't Control?

hook.text: Two drivers run red lights. One kills a pedestrian. The other doesn't. Same recklessness, different outcomes.

buildup.text: Moral luck: factors beyond your control influencing how morally responsible you're judged to be.

discovery.text: Thomas Nagel identified four types: resultant, circumstantial, constitutive, and causal.

twist.text: If you were born in 1930s Germany, would you have resisted Nazism? Most people wouldn't.

climax.text: The tension: we want moral judgment to be fair. But we routinely judge based on outcomes.

punchline.text: You're judged by outcomes you can't fully control. That's not fair.

quiz.question: What is 'moral luck'?
options: Factors beyond one's control that influence moral judgments about responsibility
The luck of being born moral

topics.title: The Trolley Problem: The Dilemma That Won't Die

hook.text: A runaway trolley will kill 5 people. You can pull a lever to divert it, killing 1 instead.

buildup.text: Philippa Foot (1967) created the trolley problem to test moral intuitions about killing vs. letting die.

discovery.text: Variation: instead of a lever, you push a large man off a bridge to stop the trolley. Same math, but most people refuse.

twist.text: The difference: personal physical violence feels wrong even when the numbers are identical.

climax.text: The trolley problem isn't just academic: triage medicine, self-driving cars, & military ethics all face exactly this.

punchline.text: Math says pull the lever. Your gut says don't push the man.

quiz.question: Why do most people approve of pulling the lever but not pushing the man, even though the numbers are identical?
options: Personal physical violence triggers stronger moral intuitions than impersonal actions

topics.title: The Prisoner's Dilemma: When Self-Interest Defeats Cooperation

hook.text: Two criminals are arrested. If both stay silent: light sentences.

buildup.text: The prisoner's dilemma: when individual rational self-interest leads to a collectively worse outcome.

discovery.text: Robert Axelrod's tournaments: in repeated games, the winning strategy isn't betrayal â€“ it's 'tit for tat.' Start.

twist.text: Climate change, overfishing, & arms races are all real-world prisoner's dilemmas: everyone benefits from cooperation.

climax.text: The lesson: morality often IS the rational strategy â€“ but only if the game is repeated & reputation matters.

punchline.text: In a one-time game, selfishness wins. In the game of life, cooperation does.

quiz.question: In Axelrod's repeated prisoner's dilemma tournaments, what was the winning strategy?
options: Tit for tat â€” start cooperating, then mirror the other player's moves

topics.title: The Veil of Ignorance: Designing a Fair Society Blind

hook.text: Design a society, but you don't know who you'll be in it: rich or poor, male or female, healthy or disabled.

buildup.text: John Rawls' 'veil of ignorance': to determine fair principles, strip away knowledge of your own position & choose.

discovery.text: Rawls argued: behind the veil, rational people would choose equal basic liberties & inequalities only if they benefit.

twist.text: Critics: Nozick argued this assumes risk-aversion.

climax.text: The veil remains powerful: 'Would you accept this policy if you didn't know who you'd be?' strips away self-interest &.

punchline.text: To test fairness: would you agree to the rules if you didn't know which.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of Rawls' 'veil of ignorance'?
options: To remove self-interest from determining what fair principles of justice would be

topics.title: The Ship of Theseus: Identity and Moral Responsibility Over Time

hook.text: If you replace every plank of a ship, is it still the same ship?

discovery.text: If you're not the same person: should you be punished for crimes committed by your 'earlier self'?

buildup.text: The Ship of Theseus: a paradox about identity. If every component changes gradually, does the identity persist?

twist.text: Derek Parfit argued personal identity is an illusion â€“ what matters is psychological continuity.

climax.text: This matters for ethics: criminal punishment, long-term promises, & national responsibility all assume persistent.

punchline.text: You're not the person you were 10 years ago.

quiz.question: Why is the Ship of Theseus relevant to ethics?
options: It raises questions about whether we are the same person over time, affecting moral responsibility
It proves that identity doesn't exist

topics.title: The Drowning Child Problem: How Much Must You Sacrifice?

hook.text: You walk past a shallow pond where a child is drowning. You'd ruin your expensive clothes to save them.

buildup.text: Peter Singer's challenge: if proximity doesn't matter morally, then we're obligated to help all preventable deaths â€“.

discovery.text: The 'demandingness objection': if morality demands you sacrifice until you're at the level of the poorest, then.

twist.text: Some bite the bullet: Singer himself donates 40% of income. But is morality supposed to demand this much?

climax.text: The tension is real: too little sacrifice = moral failure. Too much demand = a morality nobody follows.

punchline.text: You can't save everyone. But you can save someone. The question is: do you?

quiz.question: What is the 'demandingness objection' to Singer's drowning child argument?
options: People demand too much from philosophers
If morality requires sacrificing until you're at subsistence level, it becomes impossibly demanding

topics.title: AI Ethics: Who's Responsible When the Algorithm Decides?

hook.text: A self-driving car must choose: hit the pedestrian or swerve & kill the passenger. Who programmed that choice?

buildup.text: AI systems make decisions about loans, parole, hiring, & medical diagnosis.

discovery.text: The 'responsibility gap': when decisions are made by algorithms, no single person chose the outcome. The programmer?

twist.text: AI systems can be biased without anyone intending it.

climax.text: Ethical AI requires: transparency, accountability, and fairness.

punchline.text: If nobody's responsible for the algorithm's decisions, then everyone is.

quiz.question: What is the 'responsibility gap' in AI ethics?
options: When algorithmic decisions cause harm but no single person can be held morally accountable

topics.title: Medical Ethics: Triage and Impossible Choices

hook.text: COVID-19: one ventilator, two patients. One is 30, otherwise healthy. The other is 70 with heart disease.

buildup.text: Medical triage: allocating scarce resources when not everyone can be saved.

discovery.text: Common triage principles: save the most lives, save the most life-years, first-come first-served, random lottery, or.

twist.text: Each principle has moral trade-offs. 'Most life-years' discriminates against the elderly.

climax.text: The lesson: ethical frameworks don't eliminate tragic choices.

punchline.text: The choice isn't between right & wrong. It's between wrong & worse.

quiz.question: Why is medical triage ethically difficult?
options: Every allocation principle has moral trade-offs; no principle avoids all unfairness

topics.title: Whistleblowing: Loyalty vs. Morality

hook.text: Your company is dumping toxic waste illegally. You report it. You lose your job, your friends, & your reputation.

buildup.text: Whistleblowing: exposing wrongdoing within an organization at personal risk.

discovery.text: Sissela Bok's framework: whistleblowing is justified when the harm is serious, internal channels failed, & the public.

twist.text: Whistleblowers are punished: Snowden exiled, Reality Winner imprisoned, corporate whistleblowers blacklisted.

climax.text: Ethical organizations make whistleblowing unnecessary by creating safe internal reporting channels.

punchline.text: The cost of speaking truth is high.

quiz.question: When is whistleblowing ethically justified according to Bok's framework?
options: When harm is serious, internal channels have failed, and public interest outweighs loyalty
Only when you have legal protection

topics.title: Environmental Ethics: Do Animals, Trees, and Rivers Have Rights?

hook.text: New Zealand granted the Whanganui River legal personhood. Ecuador gave rights to nature in its constitution.

buildup.text: Environmental ethics: expanding the moral circle beyond humans to include animals, ecosystems, and future generations.

discovery.text: Peter Singer: any being that can suffer has moral status.

twist.text: Deep ecology goes further: nature has intrinsic value independent of its use to humans.

climax.text: Climate change is an intergenerational ethical crisis: current generations benefit while future ones pay the cost.

punchline.text: Ethics kept expanding: from tribe to nation to humanity.

quiz.question: What does 'deep ecology' argue about nature?
options: Nature is only valuable if humans use it
Nature has intrinsic value independent of its usefulness to humans
Ecology is a deeply complex science

topics.title: Whistleblowing: Loyalty vs. Justice

hook.text: She discovered her company was poisoning groundwater. Reporting it would cost her career and her family's income.

buildup.text: Whistleblowing pits loyalty to your group against duty to the public. Every ethical framework gives a different answer.

discovery.text: Consequentialists weigh harm prevented vs. harm caused. Deontologists ask if silence makes you complicit.

twist.text: Virtue ethicists ask: what kind of person stays silent? But loyalty is also a virtue. The frameworks genuinely conflict.

climax.text: Most real whistleblowers suffer. Laws protect some, but social punishment is severe. Ethics doesn't guarantee safety.

punchline.text: Doing the right thing rarely comes with a manual.

quiz.question: Why is whistleblowing an ethical dilemma?
options: It involves genuine conflict between loyalty and justice
